newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Farm ministers to tackle veterinary package on Tuesday.
newsitem.headline: Farm ministers to tackle veterinary package on Tuesday.

text.p: Farm ministers will try to tie up a veterinary package when they resume a two-day meeting at 1030/ 0930 GMT on Tuesday, an EU official said.
Bilateral talks were continuing as the Irish EU presidency tried to carve out a compromise agreement on phasing out veal crates and improving the diet of calves.
But chances of success looked slim, with French and Italian farmers leading protests that the changes would result in crippling extra costs and darken the white meat prized by consumers.
A Commission proposal to ban tissue from sheep, goats and cattle believed to be infected with either scrapie or mad cow disease was likely to be rejected, officials added.
A majority of member states, led by Germany, believe that the measures are excessive given that their livestock is free of either disease.

But Farm Commissioner Franz Fischler, noting that recent British and French research has shown that sheep can be infected with mad cow disease, has argued that no country is risk-free and that public health must be protected at all cost.

British Agriculture Minister Douglas Hogg is due to report to the Farm Council on progress in eradicating mad cow disease, on plans to implement a selective cull of an extra 100,000 cattle most at risk and the next step in easing a ban on British beef.
Although Britain will only formally present proposals to the Commission early in 1997, it wants firstly to relax curbs on cattle certified to be free of mad cow disease.
Grass-fed herds in Northern Ireland, where a computerised tracking system has operated for the past six years, would be the first to benefit.

The Farm Council is due to adjourn at 1230/1130 GMT to sign an agreement with New Zealand on the mutual recognition of veterinary standards, the first in a series the EU is negotiating with its main trading partners.
Ministers are then invited to a luncheon to mark the 100th anniversary of the Verona agri-food fair at the Brussels Europa Hotel.
The Farm Council is expected to end by 2000/1900 GMT when the Irish hold a reception to celebrate the end of their six-month presidency.
